content.raw:
the pr2 fails to load with libsdformat9 because it has mal-formed script elements

* #!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/pr2/model.sdf#lines-599

I think we need to relax the strictness of the Material DOM parsing
content.html:
the pr2 fails to load with libsdformat9 because it has mal-formed script elements

  • #!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/pr2/model.sdf#lines-599

I think we need to relax the strictness of the Material DOM parsing

there is an sdformat pull request that exposes the original version from which an sdf document was parsed:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/640

that API could be used with a patch like the following to relax the strictness of the error checking for sdf < 1.7

diff -r eac446d21115 gazebo/physics/Model.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/Model.cc   Thu Jan 09 08:59:01 2020 -0800
+++ b/gazebo/physics/Model.cc   Thu Jan 09 09:35:52 2020 -0800
@@ -29,6 +29,7 @@
 #include <boost/function.hpp>
 #include <boost/thread/recursive_mutex.hpp>
 #include <ignition/math/Pose3.hh>
+#include <ignition/math/SemanticVersion.hh>
 #include <ignition/msgs/plugin_v.pb.h>
 #include <sstream>

@@ -76,10 +77,13 @@
 //////////////////////////////////////////////////
 void Model::Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)
 {
+  ignition::math::SemanticVersion sdfOriginalVersion(_sdf->OriginalVersion());
+
   // Create a DOM object to compute the resolved initial pose (with frame
   // semantics)
   sdf::Errors errors = this->modelSDFDom.Load(_sdf);
-  if (!errors.empty())
+  if (sdfOriginalVersion >= ignition::math::SemanticVersion(1, 7)
+      && !errors.empty())
   {
     for (const auto &error : errors)
     {

patch edited with ParsedVersion -> OriginalVersion

content.raw: with the latest changes that check the original sdf version, I can load `worlds/pr2.world`, but if I click to insert a PR2 into a simulation using gzclient, it doesn't work, because [gazebo::gui::ModelMaker calls sdf::readFile](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a72fc496e1952f11dca3c69edfc5b221b7c8544e/gazebo/gui/ModelMaker.cc#lines-114), which up-converts to 1.7, then sends that sdf string to `~/factory`. Perhaps we could use `sdf::convertFile` instead of `sdf::readFile` to try to keep it at its original version?
content.html: with the latest changes that check the original sdf version, I can load worlds/pr2.world, but if I click to insert a PR2 into a simulation using gzclient, it doesn't work, because gazebo::gui::ModelMaker calls sdf::readFile, which up-converts to 1.7, then sends that sdf string to ~/factory. Perhaps we could use sdf::convertFile instead of sdf::readFile to try to keep it at its original version?

content.raw:

content.html:
I've added an overload of sdf::readFile with a boolean parameter to disable conversion to the latest sdf version, which should help with this:

this seems to fix inserting a PR2 from the gui (requires that sdf PR):

diff -r a72fc496e195 gazebo/gui/ModelMaker.cc
--- a/gazebo/gui/ModelMaker.cc  Tue Jan 14 14:10:54 2020 -0600
+++ b/gazebo/gui/ModelMaker.cc  Wed Jan 15 10:56:18 2020 -0800
@@ -111,7 +111,8 @@
   this->dataPtr->modelSDF.reset(new sdf::SDF);
   sdf::initFile("root.sdf", this->dataPtr->modelSDF);

-  if (!sdf::readFile(_filename, this->dataPtr->modelSDF))
+  sdf::Errors errors;
+  if (!sdf::readFile(_filename, this->dataPtr->modelSDF, false, errors))
   {
     gzerr << "Unable to load file[" << _filename << "]\n";
     return false;

content.raw:
On a 1.7 SDF file, this places the model on `0 5`, should it be on `5 5`?

```
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
```
content.html:
On a 1.7 SDF file, this places the model on 0 5, should it be on 5 5?

    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>

content.raw: is that in a world? not a nested model?
content.html: is that in a world? not a nested model?

content.raw:
Directly in the world.

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
content.html:
Directly in the world.

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

content.raw: yeah, we're not considering `//model/pose/@relative_to` in the world scope
content.html: yeah, we're not considering //model/pose/@relative_to in the world scope

content.raw:
This works inside `<model>` though, just not inside `<include>`:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="M">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="L">
        <visual name="V">
          <geometry>
            <sphere>
              <radius>0.5</radius>
            </sphere>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```

![relative_to.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3597364966-relative_to.png)
content.html:
This works inside <model> though, just not inside <include>:

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="M">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="L">
        <visual name="V">
          <geometry>
            <sphere>
              <radius>0.5</radius>
            </sphere>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

content.raw:
It turns out that the sdf version of the included model was 1.6 and so frame resolution was skipped for it. But since the containing world is 1.7, the model's pose should be able to use frame semantics. My proposed solution is to check if the containing world's DOM was loaded successfully before checking for sdf version. If it was, it doesn't matter what the included model's version is, we can use the model DOM from the world. 

This raises an interesting issue though. If an included model is 1.6, but the world is 1.7, Gazebo is going to load everything as 1.7 and may fail if the included model does not contain a valid 1.7 sdf.
content.html:
It turns out that the sdf version of the included model was 1.6 and so frame resolution was skipped for it. But since the containing world is 1.7, the model's pose should be able to use frame semantics. My proposed solution is to check if the containing world's DOM was loaded successfully before checking for sdf version. If it was, it doesn't matter what the included model's version is, we can use the model DOM from the world.

This raises an interesting issue though. If an included model is 1.6, but the world is 1.7, Gazebo is going to load everything as 1.7 and may fail if the included model does not contain a valid 1.7 sdf.

content.raw: maybe we should make a separate branch / PR for this?
content.html: maybe we should make a separate branch / PR for this?
